item.title: Is EU data protection law violated by Facebook and the USA? The CJEU hearing in Schrems.
item.description:
Simon McGarr, a solicitor at McGarr Solicitors, provides an overview of the Schrems v Data Protection Commissioner case heard by the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU). The case revolves around Austrian law student Max Schrems’ legal challenge concerning the transfer of his personal data from Facebook to the United States. Schrems argues that such transfers violate his data privacy rights due to the risk of mass surveillance under US law...

item.title: Live. Die. Repeat. Is the 'Privacy Shield' deal stuck in a never-ending cycle of repeating the same mistakes like in the movie 'Groundhog Day'?
item.description:
Steve Peers While the USA is globally recognized, some of its customs remain perplexing. Take “Groundhog Day,” where the presence or absence of a groundhog’s shadow on February 2nd supposedly predicts six more weeks of winter. Beyond the USA, it’s more famous as a film where Bill Murray relives the same day, striving for perfection and Andie MacDowell’s affections. item.title: Is Europe v Facebook the start of the end for NSA surveillance of EU citizens?
item.description:
The ‘Europe v Facebook’ Case: Challenging US Data Surveillance in Europe Since Edward Snowden’s revelations about the NSA’s extensive spying activities, concerns have grown about the effectiveness of US data protection, particularly for EU citizens who benefit from stronger protections under the Data Protection Directive. One concern is the NSA’s ability to access communications processed by US-based social media companies like Facebook. The Irish High Court’s recent decision to refer questions in the ‘Europe v Facebook’ case to the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) could potentially lead to the end of NSA access to EU citizens’ data...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/is-europe-v-facebook-the-start-of-the-end-for-nsa-surveillance-of-eu-citizens/

item.title: Examining the ECtHR ruling in the case of Big Brother Watch: part 1
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex A recent court decision tackles the increasingly relevant issue of secret surveillance, a topic that has gained more attention since Edward Snowden’s revelations. This extensive ruling examines three cases against the UK’s Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 (RIPA), now largely revoked. These cases, brought by Big Brother Watch, the Bureau of Investigative Journalism and Alice Ross, and 10 Human Rights Organisations, challenged RIPA’s provisions on bulk interception of communications, acquisition of communications data, and data sharing between the UK and the US...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/examining-the-ecthr-ruling-in-the-case-of-big-brother-watch-part-1/
